recipeInstructions.text: Crack the eggs: Crack 2 large eggs into a custard cup.
TIP:  Never crack eggs directly into a pan-always crack them into a cup or ramekin. It's the only way to make sure they cook evenly, and you can pour them into the pan right where you want them.
Heat the pan: Place an 8-inch nonstick skillet over low heat and add 1 tablespoon unsalted butter (don't dare skimp). Brush the butter around the pan.

Add the eggs: When the butter stops foaming, pour the eggs into the pan, then quickly lift the handle just enough for the eggs to pool slightly on the far side. This will prevent the thin albumin from running out all over the pan.

Flip the eggs: After 10 to 15 seconds, smoothly lower the handle. Wait another 10 seconds, then lightly jiggle the pan just to make sure that nothing is sticking. Season with 1 pinch of kosher salt and 1 grind of black pepper and cook, still over low heat, for 1 to 11/2 minutes.

Jiggle again and examine the whites for opaqueness; when they're fully set but not hard, it's time to flip. Here comes the hard part: Flip the eggs by pushing the pan away from you and snapping the far edge upward. As the eggs turn, try to bring the pan up to meet them.

Return the pan to the heat and slowly count to 10. Re-flip the eggs to their original side. (This time it won't be so difficult.) Slide onto a warmed plate and serve immediately with toast for wiping up all the goodness.
TIP: Never flip the food up and bring the pan down. Try to meet the food with the pan as best as you can, thus preventing a hard-and potentially yolk-busting-landing.

review.reviewBody:
I love the responses from people who never did this.

This method (it's not a recipe) is a joke. What happened to Alton. He overcomplicates everything and when he was Oz he exclaimed "don't eat this EVER" like a deranged lunatic.

Anyhow, eggs over easy are very simple to make. Provided you LEARN the SKILL of flipping the egg withOUT breaking the yolk. Once you master this SKILL then you can uses whatever method you want to fry them. Until then, write-ups or methods like this are useless because they fail to teach people HOW to flip an egg withOUT breaking it.
Good recipe but def not perfect, i prefer a hot cast iron pan, need the egg white to get nice brown crispy edges adding more flavor & texture

My go-to for making eggs over easy! I like serving these over a lunch rice bowl with veggies and sriracha. 

(I've used a spatula spoon for the careful flip and that works well too.)

Shouldn't step 5 be titled "cook the eggs" and step six be "flip the eggs"? If you tried to flip them that early in the cooking process I think it would be messy.  Really great recipe. The key to flipping is commitment. When it's time, you have to go for it!
Hands down the best eggs over easy that I've ever had anywhere. It's hard to believe that something so simple can be this good.
This was my first time trying over easy eggs. I chickened out in the flip but they still turned out great! Thanks for the step by step instructions!

Alton-  You didn't mention the temp. of the eggs.  Room temperature eggs are much easier to cook than cold ones straight from the fridge.  Very difficult to get a good over easy from a cold egg.  I usually drop them in a large pan of warm water while I prep everything else.  By the time I'm ready to cook, the eggs are closer to room temp.

Oh my god...so good!  I followed A. B.'s recipe precisely and ended up with the best eggs over easy I've ever had.  I even managed to flip the eggs in the pan without breaking the yolks.  I can't wait to make this dish for my family.
Cooked perfect over easy eggs this morning.  Thank you Alton Brown!
Flip the eggs over the sink the first few times till you get the hang of it.

It's pretty basic, but I totally agree with always breaking your eggs into a ramekin, not only so you add them at the same time, but also to make sure a yolk is not already broken. And don't be shy, when flipping them, you can use a spatula if you want.
still haven't got the flipping bit down, but working on it, thanks so much for this lesson !!

I think this is all well and good if one is using an omelet pan...But I really, really like using my cast iron skillet for eggs (and lots of other food),  Not a real good way to do the flip thing.  I just have to be satisfied with using a spatula (pancake turner for those non-Southerners out there).  But 5 stars because I just about everything Alton does.

To get the knack of flipping eggs, take a tip from Denny's cook trainees. Practice your flipping skills by flipping a slice of bread in a cold omelet pan, which has gently sloped sides that facilitate the flipping motion.

Also, while non-stick pans are great, I'm learning that stainless steel pans work, IF you keep the heat low enough to prevent sticking, and use enough butter/oil. Low heat seems to be the deciding factor with stainless steel and eggs.
